What do you think of the music that is really popular with teens?

Do you realize you're asking an age-old question?
 
 Every generation needs its own music. If today's teens have found their own beat, good for them.

And what teens? They don't all listen to the same thing. Some are into pop. Some into hip-hop. Some new rock. There are also many who have been turning back to 70s and 80s rock (thank you Guitar Hero). My 13 year likes rock - especially if it has a latin or Caribbean feel (Santana and Bob Marley are current faves.)

 What music in particular would that be? Not up on what teens are into these days, and as Jito pointed out, kids are listening to all sorts of things. 
 
 My 2 y/o daughter loves the Grateful Dead and the Doors. -I knew there was a reason I liked that kid.
I think the backing tracks are too noisy and cover up the vocals.

What do you think of the music that is really popular with teens?

 
 The same thing my dad thought about my music when I was a teen; NOT MUCH! I just have a more open mind than he did as I allow it to be played in my car, where as he wouldn't allow it in his. 
 
 I was such a brat though, I got revenge on him. I used to go out to his Lincoln, turn the stereo to WBCN Rock in Boston, crank it up, and turn on every other feature that car had as high as it would go, so when he started the car in the morning all 9 speakers would blow him out of the car, the wipers would go, the heat would blast on high. Just the fact that I'm alive is evidence of how good and patient a man he was. But man did he hate our rock and roll music. And I must say, if he were alive today, I think he would look back on my classic rock with fond memories. I know I do. Clapton and Hendrix could make a guitar sing compared to what these kids do today. And forgive me for referring to Clapton in the past tense, cuz he can still do it today. emoticon_xgood

Carlos Santana, Jimmy Page, Eddie Van Halen are all yummy, too. And for the young punks you ought to check out Jack White.

 
 Agreed on all counts. These guys could make a guitar talk. An interesting story; when I was 14, my best friend who is catholic, invited me to join him on an outing with the CYO. Because it was a religious group, my folks let me go. It cost like 15.00 for the day trip which included transportation on a bus, meals and tickets to see a concert by the Cream and Vanilla Fudge. The Fudge was a suicide band and completely demolished their instruments during their finale. This was 1967, so we are going back to the beginning when R&R was just discovering itself. Here's the Cream performing White Room, a R&R Classic. YouTube - CREAM : White Room And here is the Fudge on the Ed Sullivan Show. YouTube - Vanilla Fudge - You Keep Me Hanging On I watched this show with my parents and when I told them this was one of the bands I saw with the CYO a year earlier, they almost went apoplectic right in front of me. Such were the psychedelic days of black lights and flower children. emoticon_rolleyes

 I loved all of the classic rock bands you mention except, incredibly, the Beatles at the time. It wasn't that I didn't like their music but I resented the worship they received by the whole world and rejected them on that basis. It wasn't until long after they broke up that I gained a sincere appreciation for their music and legacy. 
 
 The fact is we had so many great musicians that made so much great music that we were spoiled in that generation. The Who's Rock Operas, J Geils, Jethro Tull and ZZ Top were also standards in my VW Bus with a killer stereo with an 8 track player, box speakers and the back seat converted into a bed with 3 inches of padding under the rug on the floor. My dad called it my whore house on wheels. emoticon_ic 
 
 We used to go up to the Kancamagus Highway Kancamagus Highway White Mountain Vacations New Hampshire Travels on the Kancamangus every weekend during the summer to camp and party. I would open the doors and crank up the music and in no time the young people from the neighboring sites would show up and by dark we had a kegger going with new friends we would never see again from all over the country sometimes, partying with us. And you know what, not one fight ever broke out between any of these people. It was truly a time of peace and love for everyone. Even the Game Wardens who would inevitably show up around 11:00 to tell me to turn the music down were cool and would sometimes have a beer with us before continuing their rounds.

 Sigh. I would not yet be a gleam in my daddy's for another two years in 1967. Clapton was really at his best with Cream. I prefer "Sunshine of My Love", though.

I like Death Metal. I wouldn't say it's 'popular' among any age group, but I've never heard anyone above the age of 40 listening to it (though pretty much all the good bands have musicians aged 40+). And I've rarely heard anyone above the age of 35 listening to it. So I guess it could be considered a thing that's more popular among teens.
